) This section covers the procedures followed when Appeals must issue a of deﬁciency. It details what Appeals employees must do when requesting preparing a notice of deﬁciency. (
) Procedures covering what happens once the notice is issued are covered in IRM
, Statutory Notice of Deﬁciency Cases. (
) A notice of deﬁciency, also called a “statutory notice of deﬁciency”, “statutory notice” or “

Day Letter”, is a legal notice in which the Commissioner deter- mines the taxpayer’s tax deﬁciency. The notice of deﬁciency is a legal determination that is presumptively correct and consists of: a. A letter explaining the purpose of the notice, the tax period(s) involved, amount of the deﬁciency and the taxpayer’s options, b. An agreement form (waiver) to allow the taxpayer to agree to the addi- tional tax liability, c. A statement showing the computation of the deﬁciency and d. An explanation of the adjustments. (

) The purpose of a notice of deﬁciency is: • To ensure the taxpayer is formally notiﬁed of the IRS’s intention to assess a tax deﬁciency, and • To inform the taxpayer of the opportunity and right to petition the Tax Court to dispute the proposed adjustments. (
) There are core procedures which must be followed when preparing a notice deﬁciency no matter what type of case. These core procedures are covered this section. (

) However, some cases with special taxes or special situations require and/or slightly different procedures. The procedures for these type cases are found in the following IRM sections: • Notices of Deﬁciency for Estate and Gift Tax Cases - IRM
• Notices of Liability for Transferee Cases - IRM
• Notices of Deﬁciency for Cases in Bankruptcy - IRM

It is recommended that notice letters use the guidelines outlined in the IRS Ad- dressing Standards ( Document 12019) when preparing the notice letter:

• Capitalize ALL letters in the name and address. • Left-justify every line in the address block on the letter. • Use the U.S. Postal Service designated two-letter state abbreviations. • Use the U.S. Postal Service street designators. (“AVE” for “Avenue”, “BLVD” for “Boulevard”, “APT” for “Apartment”, etc.) A list of the street designators can be found in the IRS Addressing Standards document. • Use the most complete Zip Code which is a

) A termination assessment is made when the taxable year of a taxpayer has not ended, or when the taxable year has ended but the due date for ﬁling the return, or the due date as extended, has not arrived (IRC

). Termination assessments may only be made for income tax liabilities. Such assessments may not be made once the date for ﬁling a full year return has passed. a. At the end of the full tax year, the taxpayer is required to ﬁle a full year return. (

) When a taxpayer subject to a termination assessment ﬁles the full year the return will be examined and the correct tax liability determined by the pliance function. a. When the tax reﬂected on the full year’s return ﬁled by the taxpayer equals the termination assessment, and an examination of the full year’s return results in no additional tax or overassessment, a notice of deﬁ- ciency will not be issued. b. If the amount determined to be the correct liability is greater than the amount shown on the return, a notice of deﬁciency will be issued in an amount reﬂecting the difference between the amount shown on the and the amount determined to be the correct liability. (

) If the taxpayer does not ﬁle a full year return on or before the proper due the Compliance function will follow “substitute for return” procedures and a notice of deﬁciency will be issued. The starting point for adjustments will be zero. Since no return was ﬁled by the taxpayer, the notice of deﬁciency will issued in an amount determined to be the correct tax liability for the year. (

) The taxpayer may protest the notice to Appeals. In some cases, it is possible for Appeals to receive the case prior to issuance of the notice of deﬁciency. these cases, Appeals will issue the notice of deﬁciency. (
